ctu.nengoros.comm.rosutils.utilNode.time.impl

Class DefaultTimeSlave

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.ros.node.AbstractNodeMain
      • ctu.nengoros.comm.rosutils.utilNode.time.impl.DefaultTimeSlave
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    RosTimeUtil, org.ros.node.NodeListener, org.ros.node.NodeMain

    public class DefaultTimeSlave
extends org.ros.node.AbstractNodeMain
implements RosTimeUtil
    Here, the Nengo simulator waits for new tick from external clock, reads its value and passes this to the simulation step. TODO: do this better, now it seems that simulator does not use the time received correctly.

      org.ros.namespace.GraphName getDefaultNodeName() 
      float[] handleTime(float startTime, float endTime)
      Three possibilities: -time master: this method publishes stopTime to the Clock topic, @see http://wiki.ros.org/Clock and returns unchanged values of startTIme and stopTime -time ignored: does nothing, returns unchanged values -time slave: reads the Clock value
      void onStart(org.ros.node.ConnectedNode connectedNode) 
      void simulationStopped()

      • handleTime

        public float[] handleTime(float startTime,
                 float endTime)
        Description copied from interface: RosTimeUtil
        Three possibilities: -time master: this method publishes stopTime to the Clock topic, @see http://wiki.ros.org/Clock and returns unchanged values of startTIme and stopTime -time ignored: does nothing, returns unchanged values -time slave: reads the Clock value
        Specified by:
        handleTime in interface RosTimeUtil
        Parameters:
        startTime - startTime of the Nengo simulation step
        endTime - stopTime of the Nengo simulation step
        Returns:
        new float[startTime,stopTime], potentially changed according to external time master

        Used to indicate that the script was reloaded during the application run.
